PRIMITIVE LAW 13 EXPOUNDED IN NAEB'S "LION BITES MAN”.
"Lion Bites Man", latest in the second "Ways of Mankind" series
produced as an adult education project by the National Association of
Educational Broadcasters, is a half-hour program exploring a primitive
method of practicing law as done by the early Ba-Ila tribe in Northern
Rhodesia in the heart of Africa.
Presented under the supervision of Dr. Walter Goldschmidt,
anthropologist of the University of California, the new offering will be
heard at -- (time) -- on -- (date) - - over Radio Station -- (name). Lister
Sinclair wrote and Andrew Allan produced "Lion Bites Man" which is one
of a subseries of six programs on Law and Justice which in turn is part
of the over-all "Ways of Mankind" series.
Special consultant for the Law and Justice subseries was Dr. E.
Adamson Hoebel, Professor of An thropology and Dean of letters and
Science at the University of Utah.
The story of "Lion Bites Man" details how Shako, a successful
lion hunter of the Ba-Ila tribe, sought satisfaction when he suffered an
arm-wound fighting a lion while Shako was defending cattle belonging
to his friend Nabotu. Shako argued, and first tried to prove on a rnan-to-
man and tribe-to-tribe basis, that Nabotu owed him "damages" for the
arm wound.
Unsuccessful in his quest, Shako made a case-at-law of the affair,
taking his argument before the Chief of the Tribe, who sat as judge. But
here Shako had to be represented by "counsel", an elder of the tribe.
Indeed, Shako won his case and a "c©u$taward" of three calves. But
his victory was an empty one, for the "attorney" took two of the calves
as his fee .
"Never employ a representative", says one of the moralist member
of the tribe, at the conclusion of the program, "for he may get more out of
the case than you do. The fearsomeness of the anthill is the long grass
upon it; it may hide a leopard, No man knows what he will find in the law
until he steps into it. "
